content.text: A 54.3 kg block is placed on an inclined plane that is 22.0 degrees from the horizontal. If the coefficient of kinetic friction is 0.25, what is the acceleration of the block?

THOUGHT 0: I'm working with the same block from problem #5 (mass = 54.3 kg) but now it's on the inclined plane from problem #4 (angle = 22.0 degrees) and there is kinetic friction with coefficient $\mu_k = 0.25$. I need to calculate the block's acceleration.
THOUGHT 1: I'll draw a free body diagram to visualize all forces acting on the block.

THOUGHT 2: The forces acting on the block are:
- Weight ($F_g$): the force of gravity pulling down
- Normal force ($F_N$): the inclined plane pushing perpendicular to its surface
- Kinetic friction force ($F_f$): the force opposing the motion of the block down the incline

THOUGHT 3: First, I'll calculate the weight of the block:
$F_g = mg = (54.3 \text{ kg})(9.8 \text{ m/s}^2) = 532.14 \text{ N}$

THOUGHT 4: Finding the components of weight:
- Component perpendicular to the incline: $F_{gy} = F_g \cos(\theta) = -(532.14 \text{ N})(\cos(22.0^{\circ})) = -(532.14 \text{ N})(0.9272) = -493.39 \text{ N}$
- Component parallel to the incline: $F_{gx} = F_g \sin(\theta) = (532.14 \text{ N})(\sin(22.0^{\circ})) = (532.14 \text{ N})(0.3746) = 199.34 \text{ N}$

THOUGHT 5: The normal force equals the perpendicular component of weight in magnitude but is opposite in direction:
$F_N = -F_{gy} = -(-493.39 \text{ N}) = 493.39 \text{ N}$

THOUGHT 6: The kinetic friction force opposes the motion and is given by:
$F_f = -\mu_k \cdot F_N = -(0.25)(493.39 \text{ N}) = -123.35 \text{ N}$
The negative sign indicates that it points opposite to the direction of motion (up the incline).

THOUGHT 7: Using Newton's Second Law, I can find the net force and acceleration:
$F_{net} = ma = F_f + F_{gx} = -123.35 \text{ N} + 199.34 \text{ N} = 75.99 \text{ N}$

THOUGHT 8: Calculating the acceleration:
$a = F_{net}/m = 75.99 \text{ N}/54.3 \text{ kg} = 1.40 \text{ m/s}^2$
ANSWER: The acceleration of the block is $1.40 \text{ m/s}^2$ down the inclined plane.
